div3.head: Piano for Sale.
div3.p:
A splendid 7-octave Piano, finished all around, and with carved feet, is offered for sale this week.
Inquire at Mr. Polster's store, corner 9th and Broad streets. oc 10--3t*

div3.head: Just received--
div3.p:
2,000 yards Carpeting, And for sale cheap for the times.
Bennett & Tolleson,
oc 8--6t* 159 Main street,

div3.head: Strayed or stolen
div3.p:
--From Capt. J. R. Robertson's camp, on the Fairfield Race Course, on the night of the 9th inst., three Horses.
First.
A sorrel horse, about 8 years old, blaze face, one white hind foot, mark of fistula on the shoulder, and is about four feet ten inches high.
Second.
A dark sorrel horse, of medium size, well formed, slight blaze in the face, stump sucker, about twelve or thirteen years old, and about the same height.
Third.
A sorrel horse, (light,) with four white feet, blase face, about seven years old, and four feet ten or eleven inches high.
A liberal reward will be given for each or all of them.
oc 11--3t* 1st Lieut. Wm. J. Hamlet.

div3.head: Five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Lost, on yesterday evening, somewhere between Richmond and the Tollgate, on Brooke Turnpike, a small Tin Box, containing papers of no use to any one but the owner.
A satisfactory description and the above reward will be given the finder, if brought to Miss Sallie Partington's, on Leigh street, between Foushee and Adams. oc 11--2t*

div3.head: Stolen--$300 reward.
div3.p:
--Stolen from my stable, on the night of 30th September, two Horses — a large blood-bay mare, in fine order, about ten years old, and a medium sized chestnut sorrel horse, with long, full tail, hair slightly rubbed on his back, and in fair order.
Also, a Saddle and Bridle, with wood stirrups and leathers.
I will give $100 for the delivery of the horses and saddle, or $300 for the horses, saddle and bridle, and thief.
T. R. Moore,
Confederate States Hospital, Petersburg.

div3.head: Strayed or stolen
div3.p:
--From my camp, near Fairfield Race Course, one sorrel Mare, with blaze face and a scar on her thigh; one large, stout, dark bay Horse, with a short tail, and one brown Horse, medium size, with a star in the forehead.
A liberal reward will be paid for the delivery of the above animals at the stable of J. J. & W. H. Sutherland.
J. R. Robertson,
oc 11--7t* Com'g Squadron Cavalry.

div3.head: Estray Cow.
div3.p:
--Came to my house, some two months or more since, a brindle Cow, with white back and tall.
The owner will please come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take her away.
S. A. Hobson, Powhatan county.
P. S.--Cow very roguish.

Came to my place, on 1st, between Main and Franklin streets, a black Mare, with a saddle, but no bridle.
The owner will come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take her away.
oc 11--3t* Jas W. Green.

div3.head: Strayed
div3.p:
--A dark-brown Mare, from the county Court-House, on the 9th inst., with saddle and without bridle.
A suitable reward will be paid for her return.
oc 11--3t* Warwick & Barksdale.

div3.head: Estray.
div3.p:
--Came to my residence, 2 Horses--one a bay, of medium size, and the other a sorrel.
The owner will please come after them.
oc 11--3t* J. T. Sutton, Jr.

div3.head: Lost--$5 reward
div3.p: --Strayed from my house, in Sidney, one large red and white Cow, about five years old. The above reward will be paid to the finder of the same.
Jas. A. Johnston.
oc 10--3t* Franklin st., between 8th and 9th.

div3.head: Twenty-five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from my residence, on Oregon Hill, a young white Cow, with brown ears and nose, the front part of her fore legs brown below the knees.
I bought her from Mr. Patrick Grace near Rocketts, and I think probably she is down that way, if she has not been taken up and sold.
I will give the above reward if she is delivered to me, or for any information that will enable me to get her.
oc 10--3t* Wm. W. Timberlake.

div3.head: Strayed away
div3.p:
--From the advertiser, living on Chimborazo Hill, (Goodman's Brewery,) a light brown Cow. The following marks are recollected: A white spot under the left fore leg, a long scar or scratch across the left hind leg, also, a smaller one on the right.
A liberal reward will be paid for her recovery, and information concerning her may be left with Mr. Fred'k Brauer, at the Old Market, during market hours, or at the above mentioned place.
oc 8--eod3t*

div3.head: Ten Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed or stolen, from the cavalry camp at Fairfield Race Course, two Mares--one a light sorrel, with the letters "C. C. S." marked on her left shoulder, and the other a light bay, medium size.
Any information of them will be thankfully received, and a reward of $10 each will be paid for their return to Captain Andrew J. Rodgers, Franklin street, or at the camp to Henry H. Gill,
oc 10--3t* Lieut. com'g company.

div3.head: Estrays
div3.p:
--Came to our place, east of the city limits, near Union Hill, about the 15th of July, a bay Mare and a gray mare Mule.
Both were in low order.
The mare is above medium size, both hind feet white, and said to be about ten years old. The mule is said to be about twelve years old, below the medium size, with no marks except from harness.
Martin & Kuhn.

div3.head: Strayed
div3.p:
--From the owner, on the 4th instant, a small bright red Cow, with a star in her forehead, top of both ears cut off, a bit cut under one ear, and giving milk when she left.
I will give $5 reward for her delivery to me or any information so that I get her again.
Dennis Keffe,
17th street, south side of the Dock.

div3.head: Strayed away
div3.p:
--On the 4th of October, from my house, on Union Hill, opposite the Methodist Church, a small red Cow, with the ends of her horns sawed off, and smooth crop on each ear. She was giving about two gallons of milk per day when she left.
I will pay $10 for her delivery to me. R. R. Turner.

div3.head: Strayed
div3.p:
--From my residence, corner of Main and Adams streets, on Sunday, Oct. 5th, a Cow belonging to the Soldiers' Home Hospital.
She is of medium size, brownish black color, with a white streak along the back and white on the legs, unusually large bag, and tips of horns sawed off.--For her delivery, besides the thanks of 50 or 60 sick soldiers, a suitable reward will be paid.
oc 8--6t* A. R. Jenkins.

div3.head: Strayed or stolen
div3.p:
--Yesterday, about o'clock, from the corner of Cary and Virginia streets, a fine, dark bay or Chesnut Mare, with Bridle and Saddle; blue blanket under the saddle.
A liberal reward will be paid for her delivery to Dr. F. Formento, at the Louisiana Hospital, (Baptist College,) West end of Broad street. oc 7--7t*

div3.head: Lost--$15 reward
div3.p:
--Between Martinsburg and Winchester, a Pocket-Book, containing $15 in Confederate and Virginia Treasury notes, and a check on the Confederate Treasurer, from A. L. Land, A. Q. M., payable to I. T. Wallace or order, for three hundred and ninety-two dollars, No. 94, dated October 1st inst.
The payment of the check has been stepped, and all persons are cautioned against trading for the same.
I. T. Wallace,
oc 4--10t* Chaplain 41st Reg't Va. Vols.

div3.head: Strayed or stolen--$10 reward
div3.p:
--From Sizer's Hotel, Manchester, my gray Mare, with Saddle and Bridle.
Said mare is four years old and about five feet high.
A reward of $10 will be paid for her delivery to me, or any information so that I can get her.
Peter Hatcher,
oc 3--12t* Chesterfield.

div3.head: Two hundred and Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Stolen, from the Spotswood Hotel, a double-cased Gold Watch, with Chain attached.
The watch is full jeweled, platina frame, with gold wheels, and there are three small diamonds on each hand.
On the inner case is engraved "F. W. C. Cook from T. P. Leathers." The chain is very heavy, two links at right angles in one piece forming one link of the chain.
The links are ornamented, and the end link has been closed into the ring with a hammer.
The above reward of Two Hundred and Fifty Dollars will be paid for the return of the watch and chain at the office of the Union Manufacturing Company, No. 231 Main street, Richmond.

div3.head: Ten Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from Mr. Charles Hanes's, in Henrico county, near the city, two red Cows, both with white spots in their faces; one had on a bell.
A reward of $10 will be paid for their delivery to the subscriber in Richmond, on 7th, between Clay and Leigh streets.
se 1--1m* John A. Mosby.

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--To go in a select artillery company from Richmond.
For one exempt from military duty, (over 45 preferred,) and of good character, a liberal price will be paid.
Call between the hours of 9 A. M. and 12 M., at the store of Williams & Elliott, No. 67 Main street, between 14th and 15th sts. oc 11--2t*

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--Immediately, for the war, in a Georgia regiment — a man over 45 preferred.
For a reliable man a good price will be paid.
Apply at General Hospital No. 19, corner 24th and Franklin streets. oc 11--3t*

div3.head: Substitute notice.
div3.p:
--A member of Company A, 13th Regiment Virginia Cavalry, wishes to employ a strong, able bodied man, who is not subject to military duty, as a substitute.
The sum of twelve hundred dollars--or eight hundred dollars, a good horse, bridle and saddle — will be paid for one that can come recommended.
Apply immediately to O. P. Kendall,
oc 10--6t* Hanover C. H.

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--For the war. A reliable man will be liberally paid.
Apply at the Richmond and Danville Railroad depot, between the hours of 9 A. M. and 4 P. M.

div3.head: Substitutes wanted
div3.p:
--Two good and reliable men over the age of 45.
Call at Wm. D. Tompkins's, Basin Bank, between the hours of 8 and 12.
oc 10--3t*

div3.head: Substitute wanted — immediately
div3.p:
--To serve in a heavy artillery company at the iron-clad battery at Chaffin's Bluff, for which a high price will be paid.
Address "J. S. P.," care of Capt. C Tacitus Allen, Chaffin's Bluff.
oc 6--7t*

div3.head: A substitute wanted
div3.p: --For the war, to go in the 1st Virginia Cavalry & Apply to B. L. Phaup, Winterpock P. O., Chesterfield co., Va.

div3.head: Administratrix's notice.
div3.p:
All persons having claims against the estate of James Barron, deceased, will present them at once, property authenticated, for settlement, and those indebted are requested to make immediate payment.
Jane Darron, Administratrix.
Midlothian P. O., Sept. 30, 1862. oc 10--12t*

div3.head: Medical College of Virginia — session 1862-'63.
div3.p:
--The next annual course of Lectures will commence on the first Monday in November, 1862, and continue until the 1st of March ensuing.
It is not intended by the Faculty to abandon permanently the customary session of five months; but it has seemed to them advisable, in consideration of the state of the country, and the increased expenses of living, to reduce it for the present to four months. The course will be conducted on the same plan and with the same advantages to the student as heretofore.

list.head: Faculty:
list.item: Chas. Bell Gibson, M. D., Professor of Surgery.
David H. Tucker, M. D., Professor of Theory and Practice of Medicine.
Beverly R. Wellford, M. D., Professor of Material Medical and Therapeutics.
A. E. Peticolas, M. D., Professor of Anatomy.
L. S. Joynes, M. D., Professor of Institute of Medicine, &c.
James H. Conway, M. D., Professor of Obstetrics, &c.
James B. McCaw, M. D., Professor of Chemistry and Pharmacy.
Marion Howard, M. D., Demonstrator of Anatomy.

div3.p: For further information, or a copy of the catalogue, address L. S. Joynes, M. D.,
Dean of the Faculty, Richmond, Va.
se 29--eod6t

div3.head: C. W. Thilow, Professor of Music,
div3.p:
Would, at the approach of the scholastic session, announce to his friends and the public in general that he will continue his instructions of the science and art of Music, especially the performance on the Piano, to those who may desire his services and favor him with their continuance.
I beg leave to remark to the public that I have taught in the late Female Institute of Mr. H. P. Lefebvre for the last nine years with the greatest success and satisfaction to myself as well as my scholars, and that I shall do all in my ability to the accomplishment of those who may be kindly entrusted to my teaching.

Applications at his residence, on Clay street, between Smith and Henry, or at Messrs. J. Wood- house & Co's Book and Music Store, will meet with prompt attention.
se 29--eod6t*

div3.head: Select School for Boys, Franklin street, between 6th and 7th.
div3.p: R. H. L. Tighe, A. M., Principals.
Rev. Robt. Gatewood, A. M., Principals.

The 10th Academic session commences October 1st and ends July 10th, 1863. Pupils are prepared either for college or business.
Primary studies receive special attention, Reading, Writing, Spelling, and Arithmetic being daily lessons.

The number of pupils limited.
Our undivided personal attention is given to the duties of our School.

p.hi: Terms per session, payable quarterly, in advance.

div3.p:
L. S. Squire's Select Classical and English School, corner of Main and 1st streets, now in its sixteenth session.
For terms, apply during school hours.
oc 10--1m*

div3.head:
Mbs.
Grace Bennett's School
div3.p: Will open in the new school-room on 9th street, near Clay, on Thursday, the 9th of October.
Girls from 8 to 11 years of age will be received.

div3.head: Musical Instruction.
div3.p: The Organist of the 1st Presbyterian Church (Dr. Moore's) will receive a limited number of private Pupils for Instruction in Music.

Applications may be addressed him, at the Spotswood Hotel.
oc 7--12t*

div3.head: Edgewood male Seminary.
div3.p:
The next annual session of this School will commence the 1st of October and close 1st of July following.
Charges per session of nine months--Board, $200; Tuition, $50; invariably half in advance, remainder 1st of February. Pupils must furnish their own lights and towels.
For further particulars address the subscriber, at Amelia C. H., Va.
se 5--1m* T. A. Crenshaw.
The Misses Forbes resumed the duties of their School on Wednesday, the 1st of October, at their residence on Grace street.

div3.head: Mrs. Pellet's School for Young, Ladies.
div3.p: Broad Street, between 10th and 11th.
The duties of this School will be resumed the 1st October, on the same plan as in former years.
Pupils in the Primary Department will receive their due share of attention from the Principal.
For terms and Circulars apply to Mrs. S. L. Pellet,
se 4--6w* Next door to Methodist Church.

div3.head: Day School for Young Ladies.
div3.p: The subscribers, late teachers in Mr. H. P. Lefebvre's school, will open a day School for Young Ladies in the building formerly occupied by that gentleman, at the corner of Grace and Foushee sts., on the 1st of October.
For further particulars call at the School building on Grace street, between the hoars of 9 and 12 A. M., Saturdays excepted.
Miss M. C. Gordon,
O. A. Ericsson,
se 4--1m* Wm. F. Grabau.

div3.head: Church Hill English and Classical School, on Broad st., between 24th and 25th.
div3.p: --The duties of this School will be resumed on the 1st of October.

Terms--Payable semi-annually in advance, $40, $50, and $60. Modern Languages and Greek extra.
[se 27--d1m*] W. L. Miller, M. A.

Miss Anderson will resume her Scholastic duties on Monday, 22d September, in the commodious room recently occupied by Mr. Pendleton, on 4th, between Main and Franklin sts. and opposite to the one taught in by her last year.

div3.head: Female School on Church Hill.
div3.p: --The third session commences the 1st October, 1862 and closes July 1st, 1863.
P. B. Price,
se 29--2w* Corner Marshall and 24th sts.

div3.head: G. L. C. Salter's English and Classical School.
div3.p:
--The tenth session of this School will open Monday, the 22d inst., in the Baptist Chapel, on 4th st., between Clay and Marshall.
Circulars, giving full particulars, may be had at the bookstores, or from the subscriber at his school-room, where, after the 8th inst., he may be found daily from 9 to 12 o'clock.
se 2--t150* G. L. C. Salter.
L. S. Squire's Select Classical and English School, corner of Main and 1st sts., Richmond, Va. The 16th session will commence on the 29th of Sept., 1862.
Prof. A. La Bombard. Teacher in Modern Languages.

div3.head: Southern female Institute, Richmond, Va.
div3.p:
This Institution will be re-opened on the first Monday in October next, with a full corps of instructors in every department.
For terms, &c., apply to the Principal.
D. Lee Powell, A. M.,
se 9--ts Box 31, Richmond, Va.
Mr. D. Turner's Select Classical and English School, Main street, bet. 3d and 4th.
The 19th Academic Year of this School will commence on Monday, the 29th of Sept., 1862.
Mr. Turner can be seen at his school-rooms, or at his residence, on 3d street, between Main and Franklin. se 10--1m*

Miss Jessie Gordon's School will be reopened on the 1st of October, at Mr. James Macmurdo's, Grace street, next door to St. Paul's Church.
se 8--1m*
Roger Martin will resume the duties of his School on the 1st of October, on Clay st., between 9th and 10th.
Roger Martin, Principal.
John H. Beale, Assistant. au 19--2m*
E. W. Cone's Classical and Mathematical School for Boys, on Franklin, between 8th and 9th sts., will reopen for its 11th annual session, on Monday, Sept. 22d.
The best Instructors in Modern Languages and Drawing will be in attendance.
Terms made known on application.
se 10--6w* E. W. Cone, Principal.

div3.head: Superior Oil Cloth
div3.p:
--Warranted not to crack in use, and an article which will stand all kinds of weather — is now manufactured in Richmond.
It possesses advantages of great value.
It is soft and pliable, and perfectly impervious to water, and may be obtained, in large or small quantities, on Cary street, between 15th and 16th, of
oc 1--1m* J. Manegin.

Clanton Duncan, Columbia, South Carolina, (formerly of Kentucky,) is prepared to fill orders to any extent in Engraving and Printing Bank notes, Bills of Exchange, &c. Engraving upon Steel or Stone.
Large supplies of Bank Note and other Paper will be kept.
au 4--2m

div3.head: Fire arms — notice
div3.p: --To the public and particularly those who may have Pistols, Rifle, or Guns, to repair such are hereby informed that they can have their work done immediately at the store on Main street, corner of 7th, by
Wm. Morgan,
fe 26--3m* Practical Gunmaker.

div3.head: Lithography, Lithography.
div3.p:
Mr. Crehen takes pleasure in informing publishers and the public generally that he has re- opened a Lithograph office, and is ready to do Lithography in all its branches.
Also, as a general Draftsman, at 166 Main street. se 16--1m*

Francis Thomas, from Paris, has constantly on hand, and will make to order at short notice.
superior Calfskin Boots, at 312 Broad street between 4th and 5th.
se 20--8m*

div3.head:
[Extract.]
Adj't and Insp'r Gen.'s Office,
Richmond,Oct. 10th, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, no. 257.--

VII.
It is hereby directed that all wheat delivered at depots on the various railroads of this State, consigned or sold to Messrs. Haxall.
Crenshaw & Co., of Richmond, acting as agents, and whose mills are grinding exclusively for the Government, shall have the preference of transportation given to Government freight over that of individuals, and also over such other freight on account of the Government as the necessities of the service will permit.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
John Withers,
oc 11--1w Ass't Adj't General.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs first Brigade,
light Division, near Winchester, Oct. 9, '62.
div3.p: all officers and men belonging to Gen. C. W. Fields's brigade are hereby ordered to report (without delay) for duty at these headquarters, or forward certificates of disability from an Army Surgeon, otherwise they will be advertised as deserters, and treated accordingly.
div3.closer:
By order of J. M. Brockenbrough.
oc 10--6t* Colonel com'g brigade.

div3.head: Sixth Regiment Virginia Volunteers.
div3.p: --All officers and enlisted men now absent from this regiment without proper authority, will report at once to Lieut. Chas. W. Wilson, or be considered as deserters and dealt with accordingly.
div3.closer:
H. W. Williamson,
Lieut. Col. Comd'g 6th Va. Reg't.
Lieut. Wilson can be found at the Army Intelligence Office, between the hours of 10 o'clock A. M. and 12 o'clock M. oc 10--10t*

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The Norfolk light Artillery Blues require twenty-five good men to fill their ranks to the maximum number.
It has been said: "To the Virginian, light artillery is particularly attractive.
It relieves him from guard and fatigue duty, it mounts him on a horse or seats him on a carriage, and carries his blanket and knapsack for him."
Those who wish to enter this favorite branch of the service would do well to act promptly while they have the opportunity, as the new Conscription law will soon be put in force.

Application for membership may be made by letter, addressed to the undersigned at Richmond, or in person at camp, on the Osborn turnpike, in the rear of Dr. Banks's house, about two miles from Richmond.
div3.closer:
Chas. R. Grandy,
oc 7--6t* Capt. N. L. A. Blues.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs 61st Va. Regiment,
Rapidan Station, October 3d, 1862.
div3.p: all officers and men belonging to this regiment are hereby ordered to report immediately for duty at these headquarters, or furnish a certificate of disability from an army surgeon.
div3.closer:
By order of Wm. F. Niemeyer, Lt. Col. Com'g.
Wm. S. Wright, Adjutant. oc 6--7t*

div3.head:
[Extract.]
Headquarters Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., Sept. 30, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 155.

General Orders No. 11, Headquarters Department of Henrico, March 21, 1862, and Paragraph III, Special Orders No. 118, Headquarters Department of Henrico, August 1, 1862, prohibiting agencies for the employment of substitutes, are so far modified that persons violating these orders will be subjected only to such penalties as may be imposed by a Court-Martial.
div3.closer:
By order of
Brig. Gen. John H. Winder.
W. Pegram, Ass't Adj't Gen'l. oc 1--2w

div3.p: All persons under the age of forty-five years, who are not exempt from military duty, will be received as volunteers in the Wise brigade, and will be entitled to a bounty of $50. Parties wishing to join this brigade will apply at once at my office, on 13th street, between Main and Cary.
div3.closer:
G. A. Wallace, Captain,
se 30--ts Wise Brigade.

div3.head: Thirty Dollars reward
div3.p: --Will be paid for the apprehension and delivery at the Marine Camp, Drury's Bluff, of any of the following described deserters from the Marine Corps:
Private John N. Carson, blue eyes, dark hair, 5 feet 8¾ inches high, and light complexion.
Private John Kelly, blue eyes, light hair, 5 feet 7 inches high, and light complexion.
Private Duncan McDONALD, blue eyes, brown hair, 5 feet 11¼ inches high, and fair complexion.
Private Michael Kenny, aged 20 years, 5 feet 10½ inches high, brown hair, hazel eyes, fresh complexion.
Private M. W. Wood, gray eyes, light hair, 5 feet 8 inches high, and light complexion.
Private John Barry.
A. S. Taylor,
oc 10--6t Major and Q. M. C. S. M. C.

div3.head: Fifteen Dollars reward
div3.p:
--For the arrest of Private Thos. G. Carper, company C, 2d Virginia Cavalry; last seen near Gordonsville.
Deserted on the 30th August.
James Breckinridge,
oc 2--10t* Captain Co. C, 2d Va Cavalry.

div3.head: Deserted
div3.p: --John Nolan, 36 years of age, 5 feet 9 inches high, blue eyes, brown hair, fair complexion, born in Ireland, by profession a stone-cutter, wears a short, thick, brown goatee, hair cut short, wore a straw hat, dark pants, and blue sack roundabout, has square, high shoulders and short neck, and has very little accent in conversation.

John Egert, 36 years of age, 5 feet 8 inches high, blue eyes, short, dark, curly hair, fair complexion, born in Germany, and when enlisted a machinist; well built, close cut moustache, wore a black glassed cap, black coat, dark pants, speaks with a strong German accent, and nose badly scratched on the right side.

George Steel, 21 years of age, 5 feet 10½ inches high, blue eyes, short light brown hair, florid complexion, born in Madison, Indiana; by profession a steamboat hand, wore a short dark goatee, very wide made, dressed in brown pants, gray over-shirt, new black broadcloth coat, brown slouch hat, and generally keeps his eyes fixed upon the ground.

John Nolan and John Egert deserted the 16th of September, 1862; George Steel deserted the 17th of September, 1862. It is probable that they enlisted under fictitious names.
They deserted from Camp Chafin's Farm, Headquarters Wise Brigade.
I will give thirty dollars reward for their apprehension and delivery to me, at Richmond, Va., or to Headquarters Wise Brigade.
G. A. Wallace,
Capt. Co. A, 59th Va. Reg't, Wise Brigade.
se 18--d1m

div3.head: For rent
div3.p:
--A brick House, with four good size rooms, and a large garret room with kitchen, on the most eligible part of Hull or Main street in Manchester.
Also, a large Room, and small one adjoining it — an excellent stand for a grocery or restaurant.
Apply from 8¼ to 9½ o'clock A. M., and from 3 to 4 P. M., at corner of Main and 12th streets, to [oc 11 --3t] Dr. Broocks.

div3.head: For rent
div3.p: --A four-story Brick Building, with the Furniture, on Cary, between 1st and 2d streets. Address "Box No. 1,019."

div3.head: For rent
div3.p:
--A very pleasant furnished front Room, without board.
Applicants address "Box 543." oc 11--3t*

div3.head: For rent
div3.p:
--A large and commodious Brick Tenement, on Wall street, now in the occupancy of Mr. J. M. Pullen.
It is well adapted for a storehouse or harness factory.
Possession can be had in ten or fifteen days. Apply to
oc 9--6t Goddin & Apperson, Aucts.

div3.head: For rent
div3.p: --The large Lot and Storehouse, on Canal street, between 6th and 7th streets. --Possession given the 1st of November. For terms apply to R. S. Allen,
oc 9--4t* Corner of Broad and 12th sts.

div3.head: For rent
div3.p:
--Two gentlemen can be accommodated with a Furnished Room, within a short distance of the capitol.
Inquire at the Lamp Store of Mr. Rex, on Governor st. oc 9--1w*

div3.head: For rent
div3.p:
--A large Lot, on 6th street, 72 by 100 feet. On the lot there is a house, formerly used as a blacksmiths shop, with six forges.
As this lot runs back to the canal, it will suit for a wood or coal yard.
For terms, apply to
R Charter,
At the Confederate States Laboratory, 7th st.

div3.head: For Sale
div3.p: --Two fine
Saddle Horses.
H. D. Cothran, Room No. 62,
oc 11--2t* Spotswood Hotel.

div3.head: Open Carriage for Sale.
div3.p:
--A fine open Carriage, but little used, and in complete order.
It may be seen at Mr. R. H. Bosher's Coach Factory, 9th street, between Main and Cary.
oc 7--6t* S. L. & J. Hutzler.

div3.head: Harness for Sale.
div3.p:
--miles & Bro., on 13th street, has for sale a few sets very superior home made Carriage and Buggy Harness.
Also, a fine Mare, 5 years old for sale.
[se 15--ts]

div3.head: Ground Plaster and Sombrero Guano for Sale
div3.p: --I have a small lot of each for sale — the Plaster $18 and the Guano $36 per ton.
P. A. Woods,
se 26--20t* Corner 11th and Cary sts.

div3.head: French Calf Skins
div3.p: --100 dozen French Calf Skins, suitable for fine Army Shoes, just received and for sale by
R. B. Stoddard & Co.,
oc 1--1m* 165 Mesting st., Charleston. S. C.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --All patients in private quarters whose names are registered at the "Clopton Hospital," must report here immediately, or they will be considered as deserters.
R. M. Patterson,
oc 8--6t* Ass't Surgeon in charge.

div3.head: Matches
div3.p: --Matches — Made in Richmond, and warranted sure fire, and proof against damp, for sale wholesale and retail at 125 Main street. Factory corner of Leigh and Fousbee sts.

div3.head: Notice to the public.
div3.p:
--Upholstering and Cabinet Making done at the shortest notice and in the best style.
Also Repairing of all description, and Renovating.
Call and see me, between Governor and Pearl streets, on Franklin street, five doors above the Exchange Hotel.
[se 18--1m*] W. J. Leb.

div3.head: Chatham Railroad.
div3.p: --notice to Contractors.

Sealed proposals will be received by the undersigned at the Company's Office in the city of Raleigh, until noon Saturday, November1, 1862 for the Gradation and Masonry of the middle division, extending from Page's to Lockville — 23miles.

Profiles and specifications, showing about the amount of work required, will be exhibited for one week prior to that date, at the Engineer's office in Haywood, Chatham county, and at the Company's office in Raleigh.
Printed proposals will be furnished contractors for their filling up and signatures.
Kemp. P. Battle, Pres't.,
Ellwood Morris, Of. Eng'r.
Raleigh, Oct.6, 1862. oc 10--6t*

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --the Richmond Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad open to Fredericksburg — On and after Monday, 13th instant, the accommodation Train of this company will be run between Richmond and Fredericksburg, leaving Richmond daily at 3:15 P. M., connecting at South Anna river, with a foot bridge and a train on the other side of the river for Fredericksburg and intermediate points, arriving at Fredericksburg at 8:15 P. M. Returning, will leave Fredericksburg at 5 o'clock A. M., breakfast at Milford Depot, and arrive in Richmond at 9 o'clock A. M.
Owing to the necessity of handling baggage across the foot bridge only hand Baggage can be allowed.
Freight trains.

On and after Tuesday, 14th instant, a Freight Train will be run daily, (Sundays excepted.) each way, between Richmond and Federicksburg, by way of the Virginia Central Railroad to Hanover Junction, thence by way of this road to Fredericksburg — leaving Richmond from Virginia Central Depot at 5:15 A. M. Returning, will leave Frederickburg at 5 o'clock A. M., and arrive in Richmond at Virginia Central Depot at 1:30 P. M. Freight for Taylorsville Junction and points beyond, must be sent to the Virginia Central Depot daily, before the hour of 2 P. M. Freight for Ashland and intermediate points will be sent to this Depot Freight arriving at Virginia Central Depot, by this company's ears, must be removed as promptly as possible.
Samuel Ruth, Sup't.
Office R. F. and P. R. R. Comp'y. oc 9--12t
Richmond, October,9th, 1862 oc 9--12t

div3.head:
Office Va. Central R. R.
Co.,
September 11, 1862
div3.p: change of Schedule.--The following trains will be run on this road on and after Monday, September 15th:

The Mail and Passenger Train, leaving Richmond at 7 o'clock A. M. for Staunton and intermediate points, daily.
Returning, will leave Staunton at 7.30 o'clock A. M., and arrive in Richmond at 6.15 P. M.

The Accommodation Passenger Train, leaving Richmond at 3.30 P. M. for Gordonsville and intermediate points, daily, (Sundays excepted.) Returning, will leave Gordonsville at 6 o'clk A. M., and arrive in Richmond at 12 o'clock M.
The Mail and Passenger Train, West of Staunton, leaving Staunton at 6.30 A. M., on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays, and returning the same days.

The Mail Train connects with the Orange and Alexandria Mail Train at Gordonsville for Culpeper and at Charlottesville for Lynchburg.
It connects at Staunton with stage lines for Lexington, Harrisonburg, and points further North.
Through tickets to Lynchburg for white persons $6.25; for servants, and for children under twelve years of age, $4;--can be obtained at this office.
Servants traveling in first class cars will pay full fare.

The Freight Train, leaving Richmond daily (Sundays except) at 5.30 A. M., and Staunton, for the West, at 6.
Da. M., on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays.
The trains will not run West of Millboro.
H. D. Whitcomb,
se 11--ts General Superintendent.

div3.head:
Office Richm'd & Pet'g R. R. Co.
July.28, 1862
div3.p: notice.--On and after Friday, 1st day of August, Tickets will be sold to the following named places at these prices:
To Augusta via Wilmington, or via Charlotte
The above tickets can be procured at the Depot of this Company, between the hours of 5 and 6 P. M.
We sell no through soldier's ticket.
J. H. Woodcocke,
General Freight and Ticket Agent
jy 29--3m R. & P. R. R. Co.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The Government having relinquished our Warehouse, we will, after having it thoroughly cleansed, resume business there in a few days.
Having one of the most commodious and best arranged stores in the Southern country, we shall be prepared to receive and store any amount of merchandize that may be consigned us, and to exhibit the goods in the most advantageous manner.
[oc 11--10.] Kent, Paine & Co.

New Auction and Commission House.
Having opened a house on 15th street, between Main and Franklin, under the St. Charles Hotel, I solicit consignments of every description of Goods, Wares, Merchandize, country Produce, &c.
Having had long experience, I flatter myself to be able to give entire satisfaction.
N. B.--Particular attention paid to outside sales for families breaking up house-keeping
Also sales of Horses, Mules, &c., at the Horse Lot, on Council Chamber Hill, every Saturday, at 10 o'clock.

Quick sales and prompt returns guaranteed in all cases.
Please give me a call.
oc 9--12t* D. F. Booth.

div3.head: A card.
div3.p: J. P. Bell. Auctioneer.
Immediate attention given, and prompt returns made for all consignments.

Particular attention given to the sale of negroes.
Charges moderate oc 6--1m

div3.head: Commission notice.
div3.p:
--Understanding that a report prevails in the country that I have discontinued the Commission Business, I avail myself of this method to assure my friends and the public that such is not the case.
I am now at the old stand of the late concern of Johnson & Pugh, devoting my entire time to the sale of Wheat, Tobacco, and country produce of all kinds, and solicit consignments from my friends and all who desire to avail themselves of my services.
Grain bags will be sent to those ordering them, to be returned as soon as possible.
All bags sent will be at the risk of the party ordering.
Thos. Tinsley Johnson,
oc 2--1m Front Building, Shockoe Warehouse.

div3.head:
Blackman & Bro.,
Publishers of Sheet Music,
Augusta Ga.
div3.p: Having removed a portion of our Music Publishing Establishment from New Orleans to Augusta, we are now prepared to fill orders for our many popular publications.

We are now publishing, "Bonnie Blue Flag;" "My Maryland;" "The Volunteer." or "It is my Country's Call;" "Missouri," or "A Voice from the South;" "The Confederate Flag;" "Southron's Watchword," &c., and can supply customers with these popular songs in any quantity.
Blackman & Bro.,
jy 1--3m Augusta, Ga.

div3.head: New Auction and Commission House.
div3.p: The undersigned have this day formed a Copartnership, under the firm of Sumner & Burress, for the purpose of conducting a general Auction and Commission business, for the sale of Merchandize of every description.

We have taken the large and commodious iron front Warehouse on Governor street, formerly occupied by Geo. J. Sumner & Co., and respectfully solicit consignments of all descriptions of goods, pledging our best efforts to advance the interest of our friends.
We shall give special attention to the sale of Manufactured Tobacco; and having had long experience in this trade feel confident of our ability to command the highest market prices.
George J. Sumner,
se 9--1m Jas E. Burress.

div3.head: New Tobacco Commission House.
div3.p:
The subscribers have taken the store formerly occupied by Messrs. Clarkson, Anderson & Co., 106 Main street, where we shall be pleased to receive consignments of Leaf and Manufactured Tobacco from our friends and the public generally.
From our long experience in the tobacco business we hope to be able to give entire satisfaction.
To Sutters, and others in want of tobacco, we respectfully ask an examination of our stock, as it embraces a larger variety of grades, and will be sold low.
au 27--1m* C. P. & J. H. Word.

div3.head: Millinery Goods, 207 Broad street.
div3.p:
--Miss Templeman is now prepared to offer to the trade a large supply of articles in the above line, among which she would mention French Bonnet Frames, French Bonnet Silks, Super Super Black Taffetas, do. for dresses; Bonnet and Velvet Ribbons; Ladies' and Misses' Kid, Silk, and Thread Gloves; Ladies' and Misses' Shoes; Black Lace Vells; Black English Crape.
Most of the above are selections from a recent arrival in a Confederate port.
se 20--d1m*

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Notice is hereby given to the owners of land lying in the county of Pittsylvania, on the line of the Piedmont Railroad, running from Danville to Greensboro', that application will be made to the County Court of Pittsylvania at its October term, 1862 to appoint five disinterested free holders to ascertain compensation to the owners of said land proposed to be taken by said company for its purposes.
Edm'd T. D. Myers,
se 16--4w Capt and Chief Eng'r.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--We are now prepared to give our undivided attention to the sale of country Produce and Manufactured Tobacco, and pledging our best efforts to please, solicit consignments.
Faulkner & Clark,
Commission Merchants.
se 12--1m* Shockoe Warehouse.

her has for sale Tracts of Land in the county of Buckingham.
The first tract contains upwards of 1,200 acres, and lies on James River, about two miles above Hardwicksville.
it is heavily wooded, and has a considerable of good timber upon A portion of it is very good tobacco land, and there are about 50 of creek plate, a part of which have been cleared and are extraordinarily productive.
To any one disposed to engage in cutting wood it presents a loveable opportunity for investment, while the hand itself is intrinsically worth more than the subscriber asks for it.

The second tract contains about 1,000 three and half miles from Hardwicksville and is heavily timbered with pine and oak. are about 75 acres of cleared land, which very well, and nearly all the land is adapted is the cultivation of tobacco.
Evidences of the ex of iron ore are abundant, specimens of the outcrop having been found very rich.
To any can supposed to carry on the lumber business, I would offer a good steam saw mill, of 20-horse power, and its fixtures; or would take into partnership in the lumber business some energetic man, who would give the business his personal attention.
I would furnish a good sawyer and foreman of my own — Persons desiring farther information will please address, Clifford Cabell.
Tye Rye Warehouse.
oc 9--1w* Nelson county, Va.

div3.head: For Sale
div3.p:
--One of the handsomest Farms is North Carolina, on the Central Railroad less than a mile from Hillsboro', and the Depot.
Good society, good schools and churches, 265 acres, fine wood land; well watered and fenced; 12 meadow; fine wheat, oats, clover and tobacco land choice fruit.
Dwelling well planned.
8 rooms outhouses good.
Possession immediately.

Cash or credit — credit preferred.
Apply to
oc 7--12t* L.P. Olds, Hillsboro', N. C.

div3.head: Land for Sale
div3.p:
--One hundred and seventy two and a half acres of Land, in Halifax county, three miles from Scottsburg and five miles from Clover Depots.
Richmond and Danville road.
for sale.
About forty acres of the land is open and well enclosed; the remainder is in original forest, well timbered; buildings comfortable.
water excellent.
Buyers are invited to call and the land.
For particulars, apply or address "Paymaster, " Scottsburg, Halifax county, Va

Land for Sale in Campbell county For sale 650 acres of fine wheat and tobacco Land, 2½ miles from Campbell Court House convenient distance of the Lynchburg and South Railroad; having on it a Dwelling-House and a houses suitable for a small family.
A great bargain will be sold to an early applicant.
Address
oc 1--d1m* J. M. Cobbs. Esq. Lynchburg

div3.head: Valuable property for Sale
div3.p:
--75 subscriber offers for sale privately the Hotel Establishment, in Boydton, in the county of Mecklenburg, Va, formerly occupied by Phill Rainey, and known as the Exchange Hotel.
It is large and commodious establishment, in good order and repair, and can conveniently accommodate one hundred guests.
It has an extensive patronage and is as valuable and desirable as any property of the kind in the county.
He will also sell a comfortable private residence in Boydton, now a occupied by Dr. John W. Williamson.
A minute to description of the property is unnecessary, as persons disposed to purchase will first view it and they are invited to do so. Having to join the arms and it being inconvenient to have it attended in to his absence, is the only inducement to sell.
The terms will be made accommodating.
Chas. R. Edmonson,
oc 4--2w* Boydton, Va.

Desirable Farm of 250 acres, in Charles city county, ten miles from the Court-House and twenty- two miles from Richmond, for Sale.--I will sell the Farm located as above, adjoining the lands of Messrs. N. Lawrence and R. Eppes, lying on the Chickahominy river.
About 100 acres are cleared, 40 acres of which are rich low-grounds, and are well adapted to the growth of corn, wheat, oats, and timothy; 60 acre are up-land, and in good heart; 60 acres are swamp land, and are heavily set in oak, cypress, and make a great deal of the cypress is fine shingle timber, the balance of the wood land is pine and oak. The buildings are all in good order, consisting of an excellent dwelling, nearly new, and all the necessary out-buildings, and an excellent well of water in the yard.

Any one wishing to purchase, can call upon me at my residence, about two miles from the place it upon Mr. J. M. Haines, at the Army Intelligent Office, in Richmond, who is authorized to sell the place, and will give them all the information desired.
Possession given immediately.
se 30--12t* Thos. H. Master.

div3.head: For Sale
div3.p:
--504 acres of Land — In the marle county, within one mile of the River Canal, situated in one of the most healthy and desirable sections in the upper country--One-half cleared; the residue timbered wooded, with commodious Dwelling and out-houses of all kinds necessary for a complete farm.
Soil kind, productive, and well watered.
will show the farm to any one calling on me, or by addressing me at Scottsville, I will respond.
Terms accommodating, or should the purchaser prefer, cash will not be refused.
se 18--ts G. W. Dillard, Agent

div3.head: Alta Vista.
div3.p:
--This beautiful Farm, consisting upwards of 900 acres, adjoining the farms of Alexander River, Samuel Branch, and Rev. C. Wingfield, will be offered for public sale on the 27th of October. It lies in Albemarle 18 miles west of Charlottesville, and seven from Warren and Howardsville, about the same distance from the Orange and Alexandria Railroad.
It produce grain and tobacco well, and could be made a superior grazing farm.
R. M. Childers resides upon it and will give information relative to its production &c. This farm was highly esteemed by its former proprietor, Robt. Rives, sent, and was the residence of the late Major Pollard.
Terms.--One-half cash; balance in one and two years. Possession given 1st of January.
Also, 10 valuable Slaves.
Chas. L. Crockett.
Executor of M. S Crockett.
Wytheville, Va., Sept.22, 1862. se 29--3w*

div3.head:
Desirable Farm of 215 acres in Henrico county, 12 miles West of
Richmond, for Sale
div3.p:
--At the request of Milton S. Cottrell, we offer for sale his Farm located as above, adjoining the lands of Dr. Coates and others, within two miles of the Mines and three of the Canal.
About two-third of the land is under good fence and divided in to three fields, which produce the usual crops of this section.
About 75 acres are in cultivation, and the balance in original timber and old-field pines.
The buildings are all in good order, consisting of as excellent dwelling, with six rooms, and the usual set buildings, and a well of good water in the yard.
There are about forty acres of good flat land adapted to grass.
Mr. Henry A. Cottrell, residing on the place, will show the same to persons who may call on him. Possession given the 1st of January next, or sooner if required.
se 23--1m* Goddin & Apperson

div3.head: Interesting to teachers.
div3.p:
--The describer offers for sale on liberal terms, either both) the Brownwood Institute, near Grange, Ga., or the Tuskegee Collegiate Institute, in Tuskegee, Ala. It is believe these institutions possess advantages of location in a college or high school, especially with the military, unsurpassed.
The outfit of each is ample the buildings are commodious and in some respect elegant.
Persons desiring information are related to Hons.
B. H. Hill, W. P. Chilton, and David Orton, of the C. S. Congress, or any other person from East Alabama or West Georgia.
Address to subscriber until 20th October. at Meshum's Albemarle county, Va; after that.
Cussela, Ala
se 27--15t* Wm. John.

div3.head: Citizens' Renovating Establishment
div3.p:
--gentlemen's Garment Cleaned and Repaired in the very old style, and at the lowest prices.--having had four years experience.
I flatter myself that work hard my hands will be done equal to that of any establishment, and at the shortest notice.

Orders to be left at Putney &Walter Main street, or at the establishment.
Maye (Ambler's Factory.) John Whiteral

By order of Brig Gen P. H. Win
